p: Once it has crossed into a human transmission chain, SARS is difficult to differentiate from other respiratory illnesses, including H5N1. According to the WHO, the “atypical pneumonia” of SARS includes symptoms of fever (higher than 38 °C), “sometimes associated with chills, […] and sometimes accompanied by other symptoms including malaise, and myalgias” 33 (muscle pain). During the incubation period, which is thought to last between 2 and 7 days, but may take as long as 10 days, patients have also reported diarrhea. 34 During the acute phase, SARS infection is characterized by a lower respiratory infection with a “dry, non-productive cough or dyspnea that may be accompanied by or progress to hypoxemia. In 10 %–20 % of cases, the respiratory illness is severe enough to require intubation and mechanical ventilation.” 35
